10.03 a.m.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have and would like to make a little correction to my statement in this House yesterday relating to the Kampong Tiong Bahru fire.

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



10.04 a.m.

    The Chairman: In clause 27 the original amendment proposed by the Member for Tanjong Pagar was,

    In page 11, line 14, at end, to add- - "; or

    (f) open or maintain, for the purpose of any activity directed towards promoting or procuring the election of a candidate at any election, any office in any room, building or any place whatsoever, whether open or enclosed, within a radius of two hundred yards of any polling station on polling day.".

    An amendment to the amendment has been proposed by the Member for Queenstown,

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Chairman, Sir, yesterday at the moment of interruption I was speaking on my amendment on the question of within a radius of 200 yards prohibiting the setting up of an election office. The Chief Minister has now an amendment which serves the purpose of my amendment, and in order to allow the Chief Minister to move his amendment, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have given thought to the amendment proposed by the hon. Member for Queenstown. I am in sympathy with him in regard to the fears that he has if such an amendment is not moved. I have also given consideration to the point raised by the hon. Member for

Therefore, I would like to move an amendment which will satisfy both sides of the House, and I would like to hand to you, Sir, typed copies of my proposed amendment.

    The Chairman: Perhaps the Hon. the Chief Minister would like to read it first.

    In page 4, lines 4 and 5, to delete "within a radius of two hundred yards of any polling station" and add a proviso-

    "Provided that every candidate or his election agent may open or maintain in his electoral division one office which shall not be within a radius of two hundred yards of any polling station and the address of such office shall be registered by the candidate or his election agent with the Returning Officer before polling day."

    Typed copies of the amendment to the amendment handed in.

    The Chairman: The amendment is in order. Copies are available, and they will be distributed.

    The Chairman: Would the Chief Minister like to comment on it any further before I propose the Question?

    The Chief Minister: No, Sir.

    The Chairman: The original amendment by the Member for Tanjong Pagar is as appears in paragraph (1) on the Order Paper. The first amendment to the amendment proposed by the Chief Minister is:

    In page 4, lines 4 and 5, to leave out "within a radius of two hundred yards of any polling station".

The second amendment is:

    In line 5, to add-

    "Provided that every candidate or his election agent may open or maintain in his electoral division one office which shall not be within a radius of two hundred yards of any polling station and the address of such office shall be registered by the candidate or his election agent with the Returning Officer before polling day."

    I will propose the first amendment. The Question is, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out", and honourable Members will be permitted to range over the second amendment in the debate.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, my view is just that this amendment is completely unnecessary. Considerable thought was given to it when we moved the original amendment, and our amendment was agreed to by the Government. Yesterday, as a result of a bright idea by the Member for Queenstown, he wanted to blot out all election offices during polling day. I then brought up the difficulties which candidates would encounter if they had no place to meet. The Chief Minister then proposed to resolve the difficulties, and save face all round by allowing one election office. I see no reason why election offices should be limited in this way. It is no more than usual for each candidate to maintain one election office for each polling district or division. The average division has about four polling districts, and I do not see the slightest objection to any candidate maintaining four election offices or as many election offices as there are in polling divisions. I would therefore suggest to the Chief Minister that our considered opinion, before the Member for Queenstown upset the general agreement on the subject, was, and still is, the best opinion, and this amendment is unnecessary.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to add to what the Member for Tanjong Pagar said. I would point out that particularly in the rural constituencies, which cover a very wide area, one office is certainly insufficient for the purpose and it would cause very great inconvenience to the candidates concerned. It might be all right in a city constituency where the areas are small and distances are not great. But in the case of rural areas, this is a considerable disadvantage to the candidate and this amendment does not meet the point at all. It could possibly be all right if we altered

Column: 2091

this amendment to "an office or offices", but as it stands I do not think it would be acceptable to this side of the House.

    The Chief Minister: Sir, I appreciate the point raised by the hon. Member for Tanglin. I am sure that his objection will not be so great if, instead of having just one office in a whole electoral division, it is permitted for a candidate or his election agent to open or maintain one office in each polling district.

    I will have no objection to it if he wants to move an amendment to this effect.

10.15 a.m.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: The Chief Minister would have saved himself a lot of trouble if he had not tried to retrieve the Member for Queenstown from the predicament in which he placed both his Government and himself yesterday by moving all kinds of gratuitous amendments at the last stage. If in fact the Chief Minister said, "Well, that is right, there should be as many election offices as there are polling districts", then why move this amendment at all? Since we are all so inextricably involved, by all means change the words "electoral division" to "electoral polling district".

    Mr John Ede: May I take the advantage to move my amendment?

    The Chairman: I was just going to suggest that we deal with the first amendment and then, when we come to the second amendment, the hon. Member's amendment could be an amendment to the second amendment.

    We will deal with the first amendment, that is,

    In line 3, after "office" to insert "for each polling district".

    I would just like to say, Mr Speaker, that I am very grateful to you for your assistance in what has become a combined operation, and I do hope that this will now meet with the support of all sides of the House.

    Question proposed, "That the words proposed to be inserted, be there inserted."

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: I do not want to be the nigger in the wood-pile in this business, Mr Speaker, Sir, but I can imagine the discomfiture in which the Government is now placed as a result of the adventures of the Member for Queenstown. If we do this - "may open or maintain in his electoral division one office for each polling district, which..."- then the grammar goes wrong in the second limb of the amendment, and we will have to add further amendments that "the address or addresses of such office or offices shall be registered."     Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Will the Attorney-General inform us whether "polling district" is a term of art in the Ordinance, and if so, where will we find that definition?

    The Chief Secretary (Mr E. B. David): Sir, if the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar will refer to section 2 of the Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections Ordinance, Cap. 53, he will find the definition of "polling district", and it reads:

    "polling district" means a part of an electoral division subdivided under section 9 of this Ordinance;.

    Mr R. C. H. Lim (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I suggest that those words to be included by way of an amendment should not come after the word "office" but rather after the word "maintain"? Therefore, the amended amendment should read as follows:

    "Provided that every candidate or his election agent may open or maintain for each polling district in his electoral division one office which shall not be.."

etc. Sir, the word "which" would then qualify "office" and not "district".

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, of all the dangerous operation one can indulge in this Assembly, the most dangerous is that of being caught and frozen in an unexpected and unpremeditated posture. I am quite sure the Attorney-General must have been aghast at himself for saying "Aye" - thereby including into the legislation of this Colony a clause which is manifestly inelegant. I ask him honestly to ask his Government whether they ought not to save face by withdrawing this amendment and going back to the original amendment as it stood, or at least try and accommodate the hon. Mr R. C. H. Lim on his point that "which" in fact qualifies not "district" but "office".

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, that amendment was proposed as a result of consultations with you, and it was your suggestion to the hon. I agreed but it was then found that his amendments were not properly and elegantly worded, and the Attorney-General therefore came to the rescue and

    The Chairman: Order. Perhaps I could allay the fears of the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar by saying that after "office" a comma will be inserted, and so will a comma be inserted after "district".

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: I do not know if it is correct or proper for any Minister to do it. But I should think that whatever the merits or demerits of your office, Mr Speaker, Sir, defects in legislation certainly should not be laid at the foot of your august Chair.

    The Chairman: I think it was all done in fun!

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is generally agreed that if there is to be compulsory voting, there must also be a public holiday on polling day. The Government has indicated that it proposes to have a public holiday declared by His Excellency the Governor, exercising his power under the Public Holidays Ordinance. However that may be, Sir, we must remember that this piece of legislation which we are pushing through this House is not only valid for this one general election but also subsequent general elections. Unless we have a proviso in the Elections Ordinance that polling day shall be a public holiday, it is always open to a subsequent Government without breaking an undertaking, because none would have been given, not to have a public holiday on polling day. I therefore propose to move this amendment to include, after clause 14, the proviso ensuring that polling day shall, in any general election, either the one we all expect in May or any other subsequent ones, automatically be a public holiday. Sir, I move, "That the clause be read a Second time."

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, am I correct in commenting on this clause? When the Bill was moved for the Second Reading I emphasised that polling day should be a public holiday. In the past many shops, department stores and business houses remained open, and it was most difficult for employees to get out and vote. The argument now is that the employers will be forced to allow their employees to go and vote. But I do not think that is quite sufficient in the present dangerous state of Singapore under the present Government. Sir, we have to think of females who are compelled to vote when their breadwinners are in their offices working. Grown-up daughters and beautiful wives will find it difficult to go out and vote by themselves without an escort. The thing is this. If there is a public holiday it will be easier for the female folk and the weak to get assistance from their men folk who could

accompany them to go and do their duty in, this very important election, when this Government must get out permanently.

    Mr E. P. Shanks (Attorney-General): Mr Speaker, Sir, at last the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar has got me to my feet. The form of this new clause that he has proposed I have agreed. But I dislike this new clause for two reasons. First, it is, at least for the forthcoming general election, quite unnecessary. An undertaking has been given that polling day will be declared a holiday, and secondly, I dislike this device of seeking to amend a not uncomplicated Holidays Ordinance by putting something into this Elections Ordinance. If the hon. Member were satisfied with the arrangements that will be made for this general election but fearful of what some future Government may do, he should, in my view, introduce a Bill to amend the Holidays Ordinance, and not seek to amend the Holidays Ordinance by the by-blow of some not immediately essential or desirable amendment to the Elections Ordinance. It seems to me that we shall only be storing up trouble for the future if we persist in altering the law haphazardly by these curious cross-references which in practice will, I am quite sure, be liable to be overlooked and cause endless trouble.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry to have got the Attorney-General to his feet to meet my argument, but I think he can at least see that an amendment is necessary if subsequent Governments are to be bound. We can always accept his Government's undertaking, but no subsequent Government has yet come about nor given an undertaking. It may believe that the proper form to maintain legislative elegance and neatness is to amend the Holidays Ordinance, but also he knows that, if a private Member moves a Bill to amend the Ordinance, it must automatically go into Select Committee. It will never be pushed through

before this Assembly is over. And I suggest to him that if at a subsequent date his draftsmen consider this to be a piece of inelegance, then the Government that is elected as a result of these provisions which we are enacting can always tidy up the Ordinance before the next body of consolidated laws are issued. I would therefore ask him to consider, or at least the Chief Minister to consider, whether it is not wiser, politically, to allow the amendment, and then at a subsequent date to get the draftsmen to tidy it up.

    The Chairman: On a point of procedure, perhaps the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar may be interested to know that a private Member's Bill does not necessarily go to Select Committee, and the Bill mentioned by the hon. It is only a question of procedure.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Whatever it is, Mr Speaker, Sir, you will realise that it is not possible for me, unless I get a Certificate of Urgency from the Governor, to rush it through.

    The Chairman: I am not arguing. I am just pointing out a point of procedure. That is all.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Sir, the Attorney General may be right. The proper thing to do would be to amend the Holidays Ordinance. But the life of the Government is only for a few days. There is no time for any Member to move a private Bill. In view of the coming election and in view of my suggestion to give escort to female voters, it is very essential that, as a special thing for this election, we pass this Bill in the interest of the public. I am sure the Government is not going to obstruct that.

What the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar seeks to achieve is that it shall be so stated in some Ordinance that polling day for future general elections should also be a public holiday. This is a matter in which I have to rely on the advice of the Attorney General. He advises me that that is not the proper way to achieve it. And now, I hear from the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar that it would be better if the intention could be stated in some form or other so that it is clear and that if the intention is made clear in this Bill, subsequent Governments can have it amended at a later date.
